Looking for a fun and exciting part-time position? Camas School District needs substitute bus drivers! Working in a substitute driver position is a great way to help students, learn some new skills, learn about our schools and their programs, and earn some extra money!
• Do you like to drive?
• Do you relate well to children?
• Would you like a competitive wage?
• Do you have a clean driving record?
If so, consider becoming a substitute bus driver today! We have several job openings available. Training will be provided for qualified applicants. Apply at http://bit.ly/CamasJobs.

COVID-19: Driver training will follow social-distancing guidelines. Questions? Call the Camas School District Transportation Department at 360-833-5585.

Discovery High School students & staff— as part of the Camas First Robotics Team 2471 — are continuing to produce personal protective equipment (PPE) for our medical community and have collaborated with Hewlett-Packard engineers to improve their initial designs. The newest face shield is called “The Mandalorean.”

Nearly 10,000 pieces of PPE have been delivered to local medical teams so far, with a socially-distancing volunteer delivery network (thank you, parents!) in full effect. Many individuals and companies have also stepped up to house 3D printers, contribute materials, donate funds, and offer up their expertise. We would like to thank you all!

Hear about the project and sneak a peek into the fabrication lab with sophomore Cole Herbert, Design Engineering Teacher Bruce Whitefield & Principal Aaron Smith: https://vimeo.com/409055073

For more info, visit www.team2471.org/infinite-resource

Supporting Teens Parent Education Event: We’re hosting a virtual parent wellness event Thurs., April 23, 4-5 p.m., that will focus on how to support our teens’ emotional health during this unique time.

Please join Jennifer McMillan for an hour of thoughts, information, and community as we work to understand we aren’t alone, we’re in this together.

We have space for 40 parents to join, please sign up on this Google Form (https://forms.gle/hGxyLewPHZALpKPW6), and you will receive a calendar invitation with a Zoom link to join the event.

If you can’t make it, or the event is full, we will videotape the workshop and have it available on our CSD Wellness page, bit.ly/CSDwellness.com, to watch at your leisure.

If you have any questions, feel free to email Jennifer at jennifer.mcmillan@camas.wednet.edu.

Over two days, the entire Liberty Middle School - Camas School District 8th grade is visiting the state capitol. On yesterday’s trip, students were guided on a tour that touched each branch of the government, visiting both the Senate and House chambers while they were voting on bills. They participated in a quick mock trial in the state Supreme Court, and visited the governor’s office, where the group was lucky enough to run into Jay Inslee himself.

After the capitol tour, they took in several memorials around campus — including a plaque that Camas students placed at the base of the Moon Tree years ago. At that time, Camas students sold Moon Pies at lunch to other students, raising the money to buy the plaque, rock base (composed of Camas Greywacke basalt quarried from 192nd), transportation, and placement.

Many congratulations and our deepest thanks to CSD's Alison Benjamin and Valerie Parbon! From the article:

ALISON BENJAMIN, CAMAS SCHOOL DISTRICT

Alison Benjamin is the leading member of the Camas Educational Foundation, which has helped fund equitable learning opportunities for students in CSD for the past 20 years. Benjamin has made it a priority to develop and implement a social/emotional wellness initiative through the foundation, aimed at reaching students and parents who are seeking support during emotionally challenging times.

VALERIE PARBON, CAMAS SCHOOL DISTRICT

Through the use of individual high-tech heart rate monitors, Camas High School PE teacher Valerie Parbon emphasizes personal fitness and overall wellness over competitive athletic achievement for all of her students. The results have helped more students feel engaged in PE class because they experience less pressure to perform well and instead are encouraged listen to their own bodies’ cues to guide their physical activity.

Congratulations to Grass Valley Elementary teacher Natalie Wilson, who has been named to the 2020 Class of the Washington Music Educators Association Hall of Fame! She will be honored at WMEA’s gala in February.

The Washington Music Educators Hall of Fame was established by the WMEA Board of Directors to give recognition for exceptional support, inspiration and outstanding contribution to the growth and development of music education, both public and private, in the state of Washington.

It was established in 1998 with a charter class of 125 members and augmented two years later with an additional 70 members. Since that time, up to 10 members per biennium are elected to the Hall of Fame.

We are pleased to share that Dorothy Fox Elementary's Lee Gilronan is being honored by the Lower Columbia Estuary Partnership as 2019 Steward of the Year!

Executive Director Deborah Marriott had lots of wonderful things to say about Lee, including this: “We have worked alongside you since 2008, and through that time brought hundreds of students from Dorothy Fox Elementary to Steigerwald Lake National Wildlife Refuge. Students plant trees, remove invasive plants, and marvel at the abundance of wildlife just minutes from their school. Your enthusiasm, even on the windiest and rainiest of days, is infectious and creates a space for students to feel comfortable outside. You ignite a spark for the love of science in your students, even if they may not realize it for many years."

Lee will be recognized at the organization's Dinner & Gala on October 10.

Great job, Lee! It's a privilege to have you as part of Camas School District.

*Joan Haugaard, Jake Howell & Carol Bruce Receive the Mill Town Pride Award*

Heart conditions are often undetectable in normal physicals and in-depth testing can be pricey. But thanks to Joan, Jake, and Carol's collaboration with the Play Smart Youth Heart Screenings program, Camas High School has offered free heart screenings to 1,398 students! CHS is now ranked the #1 Play Smart School for all of Oregon and Washington and has the #4 and #5 top daily volume distinction for all Washington schools. Given that Play Smart has offered 300+ screening events, maintains 113+ screening partnerships, and has screened 34,000+ students, this is a huge accomplishment. Thank you for bringing this life-saving service to our students, Joan, Jake, and Carol!

Joan, Jake & Carol received the Mill Town Pride Award at the Camas School Board meeting on Sept. 9.

Pictured: School Board Vice President Connie Hennessey, Joan Haugaard, Jake Howell & Assistant Superintendent Charlene Williams. (Not pictured: Carol Bruce)

shared_text:
Dorothy Fox Elementary PTA is at Lowe's Home Improvement (18801 SE Mill Plain Boulevard, Vancouver, WA).
August 29, 2019 at 6:34 PM · Vancouver, WA ·

A huge THANK YOU to Lacamas Lake Lowe’s Store employees and the Lowe’s Heroes Team for all your hard work and very generous donations!

During two of the hottest days this summer and just in time for back to school, some of our local heroes were busy removing and replacing weed barrier, bark chips and edging in the Dorothy Fox School Garden! They also built, installed and filled two beautifully crafted raised garden beds, assembled a hand washing station and garden shed and donated all the tools they used along with child sized garden gloves and tiles. The crème de la crème is on its way… A wood crafted information board which will be used to display educational materials and interchangeable tiles to feature future student artwork.

We can hardly wait for students to see the school garden, jump in and get their hands dirty and experience science in action!

CHS Green Team has some exciting news!

Last week, with partnership from HP and Vancouver Eye Care, we received Idle-Free Zone signs for our parking lots. Our proposal for these signs earned Camas High School a Washington Green Schools Transportation Certification as well as the status of Gold Level WA Green School. The overall goal was to decrease the carbon footprint of CHS.

The objective of this project was to install 8 signs that designate Camas High School as an idle-free zone. The criteria for the signs included durability, effective positioning, and to reduce idling rates by at least 50%. Green Team leaders collected data that showed an average 51% of cars in the parking lot were idling after school. Initial data after installation shows a decrease of idling by an average of 41%.

Two Green Team leaders, President Andrew Kim and Alex Gee, presented their research at the HP Science Fair on June 10. Their research and findings were well received at the fair. The CHS Green Team is looking forward to continuing data collection and continuing to decrease idling at CHS.

At our board meeting on Monday, we said thanks to these first responders for saving a life!

One early morning in March, one of our high school students went into cardiac arrest at his neighborhood bus stop. Thanks to the extremely quick response of several extraordinary people in the area, he was able to get the medical attention he needed and is now busy making a full recovery from open-heart surgery. In no uncertain terms, the actions of these people saved his life:

• Neighbor Justin Lottig – who was walking home, after dropping his kids off at Grass Valley Elementary – performed CPR at the bus stop and kept our student breathing until paramedics arrived;

• Grass Valley parent Katie Parker, who called 911 and helped Justin the scene;

• Classmates Isabelle & Jasmine Domenech, who notified our student’s family and kept peace on the bus, and

• The professionals of the Camas-Washougal Fire Department who played an enormous role in giving him the very best possible outcome.

#MillTownPride

Sixteen members of Skyridge Middle School's Builders Club – a new service organization for students – participated in a game of beanbag baseball on Tuesday against a team of senior residents at The Quarry Senior Living.

The Quarry team, made up mostly of 90-year-old+ residents, didn’t take it easy on the students and quickly led the game in the first two innings. The Skyridge students got into a rhythm and eventually won the game 26-15.

As one resident put it, “These kids are so good and are very kind, too!”

Both teams enjoyed a post-game cookie celebration at which time the Skyridge students handed out handmade paper flowers to each resident.

Said Builders Club Advisor Kim Cooper, "I was incredibly impressed because the kids were patient, kind, attentive, and gentle toward their 90-year-old+ 'opponents.' They made Camas proud with one small game."

> Judgments are made solely on the basis of ability demonstrated on the candidate recordings.
> Judging criteria are similar to those used by DOWNBEAT in its album Reviews section.
